bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Harry H. Woodring, August 30, 1937

div1.p: Andrus requests clarification of the definition of his role in the yellow fever experiments published in the Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Harry H. Woodring, August 30, 1937
div1.opener:
Hon. Harry H. Woodring,
The Secretary Of War,
Washington, D. C.
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Sir:
div1.p:
Public - No. 858 - 70th. Congress - “An act to recognize
the high public service rendered by Major Walter Reed
and those associated with him in the discovery of the
cause and means of transmission of yellow fever” - reads,
in part, as follows:

“ * * the Secretary of War be, and he is hereby, author-
ized and directed to publish annually in the Army Register
a roll of honor on which shall be carried the following
names: Walter Reed * * James A. Andrus, (Corrected by
H. R. 11899 - 71st. Congress, 2d. Session - to read John
H. Andrus) * * and to define in appropriate language the
part which each of these persons played in the experimen-
tations * * ”

The roll of honor, as published, ascribes motives of a
number of volunteers while definition of the part I played
is far from complete and does not even give credit for the
“character excellent” on my discharge.

I respectfully request that definition of the part played
by me be revised to incorporate the following facts:

John H. Andrus, private Hospital Corps, voluntarily nur-
sed yellow fever patients during an epidemic at Guanajay
Barracks in July-August, 1900. At the side of two men
as they died, and nursing others critically ill, he
feared the disease. Later, at Columbia Barracks, he
was detailed for duty with Major Reed's Commission.
Much of his work, breeding and caring for mosquitoes to
be used in experiments, was in the small laboratory in
which Major Reed and Lieutenant Carroll spent many hours
in discussion and at their microscopes. He became so
interested in the work of the Commission that, at a time
when a volunteer had withdrawn and Major Reed had declar-
ed his intention to order his own innoculation, Andrus
volunteered for experiment and was infected with yellow
fever by an injection of blood from an experimental case.
He became ill Jan. 28, 1901, being twelfth in the series
of cases at Camp Lazear. He left the Army Apr. 24,
1902, with character excellent.

To substantiate the facts presented I offer the following:
“Nursed yellow fever” - See copy of letter from Act'g Asst.
Surgeon J. F. Dunshie. Also 1st. endorsement on appli-
cation for transfer for duty in China or Philippines.
“Duty with Commission” - Have no documentary evidence.
Brigadier General A. E. Truby (retired) can verify.
“Major Reed's intention to order his own innoculation” -
No documentary evidence. General Truby can probably
confirm as, at the time, Lieutenant Carroll pleaded with
the Major not to order his innoculation on the ground that
his age and poor physical condition (The Major had but
recently recovered from an illness) would make the Major's
innoculation very hazardous. I have no doubt but that
Lieutenant Carroll called upon General Truby (then a first
lieutenant) for assistance in dissuading the Major.
The Major and General Truby were veryb good friends.
“Character excellent” - See photostat of discharge certif-
icate.

Please have all enclosures returned to me when they have
served your purpose as I value them very highly.
